reviews.review_msg: His lectures are very interesting and he keeps it lighthearted. The midterm exam was so easy he used questions he provided in the sample midterm for us beforehand and a lot of it was based on the lecture.

Avoid this course! Quizzes worth 30% of your grade and are based on the tiniest details of lengthy chapter each week. You would expect the main themes of the chapter to be quizzes but nope! You mess up on the quizzes and your grade is done. Midterm so confusing - need tiniest details to be remembered and applied. Don't recommend save ur GPA

Worst upper div course taken thus far, incredibly unclear with how exams and papers will be graded, in addition to what will be on exams in the first place. Weekly readings and tutorial questions split between online readings and 2 textbooks total over 100 pages for some weeks alone, does not cover a lot of test materials in lecture due to time :(

Close to 100 pages of reading each week from two textbooks that were either quizzed on or on the midterm/exam.Course was extremely disorganized (final exam content was ambiguous). Professor assigned far too many discussion questions (10-25) for tutorial to the point that we would never finish them (although all were examinable).

This was one of the hardest classes I've ever taken in Crim. 2 textbooks, one for weekly quizzes worth 30% and one for exams/discussion.Tutorials discuss questions from the other textbook, also on exams. Additional to the 2 textbooks, there are also articles assigned which are included on exams. If you dont LOVE philosophy, avoid this class 100%
Way too much reading and the quizzes are impossible. Take 335 instead for your legal certificate, this isn't worth it

Probably the worst upper div crim class I've taken, although the class content was interesting- readings and lectures were from 2016 and used from another professor's course. Therefore, memorizing outdated legislation and policy was essentially useless. Super disappointing given the very interesting content of the class.
With around 10 readings a week at a minimum of 20 pages per reading, do not take this course if you're taking any other courses.

Great prof. Very nice and understanding of everything. Structured the class well. Marking was fair. Final was fair as well however it was the longest exam I have ever written. Would recommend him (in class).

There's ALOT of reading for this class. There are weekly quizzes coming from a separate textbook that isn't tested on the midterm/final (therefore, he hardly touches on this in class so you have to prepare for it yourself). The weekly quizzes are weighed the heaviest part of your overall mark. The term paper is also very hard.

Took this online. This course is VERY HEAVY on the reading. 1 unit  2 weeks with an average of 10+ online articles, 8+ case law readings, the study module, and 1-3 chapters of the textbook. The course is interesting but there is a lot to remember. Midterm and final have short/long answer questions only. Final is cumulative.

The tests in this class are insane. You get a cheat sheet but it doesn't even help. Macalister is a very knowledgeable and respected prof but the content of this class is extremely hard and much harder when you take it with him. Even studying like crazy doesn't guarantee a decent grade. I recommend taking the course with Brockman or Bowbrick.

David is a brilliant professor who knows his material inside out; however, he is not the best lecturer as his lectures are quite boring and unclear. Lecture slides will not help much so get ready to read!!
He's an amazing prof. Crim 338 is a tough course. Its philosophy and is difficult for a typical criminology student, like me.  However, MacAlister is great and always give interesting lectures.

In addition to reading a chapter from the Hart book every week for the weekly quizzes (worth 30%) there is a significant amount of readings for the discussion questions every week (the discussion questions are directly taken and put on midterm so also important). The term paper for the class is 6-8 pages and once again requires you to read 80pgs

You definitley have to put in some effort. There are 10 quizzes all 6 multiple choice questions worth 30% of your grade. The questions come from the weekly assigned chapters in another small book Midterm was all short answer questions that came from the list of "discussion" questions. Final was all M/C.  Paper is short but requires a lot of reading
Although interesting, he sucks at keeping on track with course outline.  Exams require a lot of work, but you  are allowed to have a cheat sheet.

This class is pretty tough. Lots of readings but he provides good lecture slides. Midterm and final are really hard, but he lets you bring in one cheat sheet for the mid term and two cheat sheets for the final.  The legal research assignment and the two other assignments plus tutorial participation should help boost your mark though

Engaging lectures. Relies on the TM for marking and discussions (we had a great one, so that worked out well enough, a great opportunity for them too). A lot of workreading but worth it if you are interested in learning the material. I have taken him before and his knowledge and humor always makes for an interesting class.

This was a pretty decent course. Two papers (~2000 words) plus two exams (40 M/C questions and 90 M/C questions). Exams were somewhat difficult in that they were very detailed. Papers were pretty straightforward. Discussions (10%) were easy marks
difficult exam material. TA's don't help you out much, your basically on your own. Requires a lot of reading. On the bright side, not cumulative!

The class is very interesting. He knows what he's talking about but at times he can be very unorganized!!! which in annoying for a class that requires you to know so much. The TA (Anita) was nice but she's laughed at us when we got our midterm mark back and told us how bad we did...Also, she was never prepared for tutorial and a hard marker!

Exams are pretty difficult, but he knows his material inside out and he is one of the nicest and most helpful profs in the dept. Lecture slides are really good because they summarize the cases and pretty much tell you what you need to know. I'm really glad I got to take classes with him and would recommend him for any class.
David knows his material inside and out. Tries to make dry material interesting by cracking jokes here and there. He's an excellent lecturer. Very organized, and clear in his lectures.

In the five years of post-secondary I have never enjoyed a prof as much as David. He is very flexible, available to discuss difficulties, he makes boring topics interesting and actually cares about his students.

Took this course online...Very interesting course! Great readings, and interesting short assignments. The textbook for this class is a good read. For final exam if the question is a bit unclear do not hesitate to ask. Happy I took this class because the topics and readings were INTERESTING.

Great professor. I came from Kwantlen, and I feel that this professor is a real teacher, not just a stereotypical white old snob of a teacher who believes that the ways he was taught are the best to teach our generation.
Really great professor - absolutely brilliant. Great legal scholar. Interesting classes and material. Keeps students engaged and genuinely wants them do well.

Entertaining lectures that prepare you well for exams.Tons of material to cover in this class with a midterm/final that are both pretty tight on time. The TA (Kouri) is helpful and runs an awesome tutorial. Just make sure to complete all the readings and the class in manageable.

Lecture slides and recordings posted online, so attendance is not mandatory. Very clear on what is expected on exams, additional assignments were fair and straightforward. Allowed the use of cheatsheets, which if done properly, help tremendously. TA Kouri was awesome!

NOT an easy class!! very knowledgeable prof but has very high expectations! class avg is 66%. DO NOT slack off and do the readings. its a lot of work for this class but david is such a good prof, he's worth having as a prof! wish he would cut down on the required readings but o well. the presentation, participation & assignment will boost your mark

midterm is tough. multiple choice is tricky. on the plus side there are many opportunities for you to boost your mark such as the legal research, presentation and participation. extremely knowledgeable prof, he seems to know the law inside out. we are quite lucky to have an instructor like him at sfu. overall, recommended.

Midterm and final were very tight on time, but heavily reliant on familiarity (not memorization). and I'm usually out halfway through. Spectacular notes, great TA (Kouri). Just review notes and Code and you'll do well.

He is the greatest. Consider yourself fortunate to be taught by such a knowledgeable and passionate prof. David is approachable, extremely nice, and funny in his way. It's not a cake walk but he makes it possible to do well if you study and put some effort into the term papers.
Interesting lecturer. Very knowledgable.

Very nice and approachable prof. The course material, somewhat, is intense but he tried to make the examples as clear as possible. He is a patient person and tried to make people happy with their mark.
David is great prof...always well prepared and is able to make an abstract subject interesting. I learned so much from him, definitely one of the best.

very helpful. be prepared to read a lot of case law. it helps for understanding the law, but it is tedious to go through. he clarifies everything. start on the paper early... it's 5000 words! overall, good prof. recommended.

He is a great prof!  Whoever said that they were not payiing for a comedian clearly does not have a sense of humour.  You need humour in life to get through tough times.  This course is super interesting and he explains the intricate stuff very well.

loves to use case law, so understand the precedent of the case, not the little facts of the case. His test are fair, but midterm was tight on time. His notes are really good, almost to good that i didn't even read the book for the final. assignments are pretty straight forward. But all in all, its like a criminal law class, learn a case and apply

David inputs humour whenever he can into lectures. He tries his best to keep students engaged and gives good examples. Exams are fair if you have a well written cheat sheet. David is a good lecturer and the exams are fair. Bonus, there are NO PAPERS for this class!!!
Crim 338 is awesome, DO THE HOMEWORK QUESTIONS, Lorinda (ta) AWESOME....notes available online so you can actually listen to the PROF.I would take a course with him again!

Prof MacAlister An AMAZING Prof highly recommended! One of the best AT SFU. He is extremely well prepared & genuinely wants students to do well! Very insightful, compelling and happy to help with all questions! Crim 338 is one of my favorite classes! I got an A, impart due to his thorough notes and willingness to help!

I had MacAlister for crim 330. Good class..yes he does use humour quite a bit and some of it can get a little offensive but it keeps you awake. Very hard midterm and final (I am a B+ and higher student and found this class hard). Make sure that you attend lecture+tutorials+know the cases for this class.

I enjoyed crim 338, it was my first course at SFU. Lorinda is an excellent TA. There are a lot of readings but nothing to be frightened about, just do and keep up with the homework questions and you will do fine for everything..The prof did not have offensive humor, notes are made available online..come to class and tut and try, you'll do fine
No Comments
No Comments
knowlegeable, interesting, helpful....keeps it light and informative and makes you think...excellent
Terrible professor. I will never take another class he teaches. Received a great grade, but only through getting clarification from others. Very unhelpful.
This prof really cares about his student's doing well.  Great guy to take the class from, made it interesting and relevant
Made a 9:30am class much more tollerable than I had expected. Great sense of humour.

I am not happy. I was looking forward to this course but I do not feel like I am getting my money's worth. Prof. McAlister makes too many jokes about serious current events and he does not have ready answers to many issues. I should have waited for another Prof.
No Comments
He rocks!  super TA also...makes a fairly drab subject interesting and palatable.

I agree with the most recent rating. I also resent the amount of humour put toward a class that deals with some very serious subject matter. I am amazed at the other comments that praise his humour.Humour is never something that I would include in my analysis of a professor's teaching ability.

I do not agree that David is good Professor. I had him at Kwantlen and he still teaches as if at that level. I am resentful of the amount of humour that he puts toward a very serious subject matter. I'm not paying for a comedian.

He is a good teacher who knows his stuff. He explains cases well and really clarifies the readings. Procedure and evidence is an awfull topic, but it isn't as bad with him. I don't think he is as funny as some people do though.
good but bland
david is the prof i learned the most from also!! course was not hard but not easy either, you have to pay attention and want to be there. fair maker!!!
Dave is pretty funny. The material may put some people to sleep while excite others. Tests were pretty difficult.
No Comments
not very well organized. I had trouble following his train of thought. seems too flirty
No Comments

David is the professor who I have learned the most from.  He is interesting and makes the course material interesting as well.  He puts his students up to a challenge and ensures they meet it.  Thank you so much David!
great class, very enthusiastic about the material.  makes things very clear, but his exams have a lot of writing and are tough - but certainly fair!
power point ... need to know lots of material
